The World Bank project team was led by Mr. Hiran Herat and included Messrs. Craig Neal, Stanislas Balcera, Hemant Shah and Ms. Yvonne Jones. This document reflects the helpful comments and generous assistance by many Croatian and other country counterpart. Most notably, it reflects the close collaboration and support of the Assistant Minister of Finance of the Republic of Croatia, Mrs. Ljerka Ercegovic as well as the active participation and encouragement of the Minister of Finance, Mr. Bozo Prka. By consolidating the design and planning work for the project, as well as the terms of references for the technical assistance contracts, this plan will serve as a reference for all key project activities by current and future project participants. This, the authors hope, will provide greater coherence and continuity of actions over the project period. Although the plan cannot provide exhaustive detail on all project activities, it is sufficiently detailed to remain a working document for the duration of the project. Thus, the project implementation team is strongly encouraged to update and revise the plan to reflect work accomplished and further refinements in the project design and schedule.

 CROATIA: Capital Markets Development Project --1 -- Project Implementation Plan REPUBLIC OF CROATIA Capital Markets Development Project Project Implementation Plan (PIP) -THE PROJECT -- Project Objectives 1. The overall aim of the Capital Markets Development Project is to support the Govemment of the Republic of Croatia's economic transformation programs, by facilitating the privatization and restructuring processes and, more generally, developing the capital markets institutions required for a modem market-based economy. In particular, the Govemment wants to strengthen: a. the policy framework for the capital markets, especially the regulation of securities markets; b. the operational capabilities of key capital markets entities, especially the securities depository, registry, clearing and settlement functions; c. the public's comprehension of the capital markets and their roles as shareholders. Project Description 2. The Capital Markets Development Project will provide technical assistance, training, information technologies and various office-related equipment and resources. The total cost of the Project is US$21.0 million equivalent, including physical and price contingencies, taxes and duties, and recurrent expenses for the three and one half years of the project. The World Bank will finance US$9.5 million equivalent of investment expenditures. The Project will be implemented over a period of four years under the supervision and guidance of the Ministry of Finance (MOF), in collaboration with the securities "depository" (VVS), the Institute for Payment Transactions (ZZPP), Ministry of Privatization (MOP) and the Republic Fund for Pension and Disability Insurance of Workers in Croatia (the "Pension Fund", for brevity).
 CROATIA: Capital Markets Development Project -- 2 -- Project Implementation Plan 3. The Project focuses on a few key initiatives in three basic project components. a. Policy Support i. regulatory and organizational development of the Croatian Securities and Exchange Commission (CROSEC); ii. technical assistance on the conversion of illiquid govemment debt instruments into tradeable securities; iii. technical assistance on portfolio management to the asset holding arm of the Pension Fund. b. Infrastructure Development: i. design, development and implementation of securities depository, registry, clearing and settlement facilities (WS), including a program to immobilize existing physical certificates and secure existing share registries; c. Public Awareness: i. mass media development (television, radio and print media); ii. mass media campaign ("air' time, printing and distribution). -- IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS -- Organizations Responsible for the Project 4. The Ministry of Finance will administer the funds under the Project and coordinate project activities through a Project Implementation Unit (PIU). The PIU will be headed by a full time Project Implementation Officer with extensive project management experience. In addition, the MOF will organize a Project Steering Committee with representatives from the major participants in the Croatian capital market. The Committee will advise the MOF on matters of substance and priority which the PIU and the project teams will bring to it (in coordination with the PIU). 5. The MOF will establish three teams to implement the various project components. (Figure 1 on page 4 summarizes the implementation arrangements.) a. Policy Support. A MOF team, headed by the Assistant Finance Minister, will coordinate the policy support activities, with participation by staff from the Ministry of Justice, the National Bank of Croatia, Ministry of Privatization, the Pension Fund, the banking, brokerage and enterprise sectors, as well as foreign consultants. This team will focus on the legislative and regulatory policy issues in the capital markets and the establishment of CROSEC. A smaller technical assistance effort will be directed at converting certain illiquid government debt instruments into tradeable securities and at strengthening the portfolio management capacity of the Pension Fund. b. Infrastructure Development. A second team will include personnel from VVS and ZZPP, and will have the assistance of foreign consultants. The team will coordinate closely with representatives from key private sector entities, such as the Zagreb Stock Exchange, the Broker's Association, commercial banks, the Varazdin OTC

This team will focus on the development of the securities depository, clearing and settlement facilities as well as strengthening the linkages between the depository and selected capital market entities, such as the exchanges, brokers, etc. c. The Public Relations Unit of the Ministry of Privatization, headed by its assistant minister and supported by a team of public relations professionals, will manage the public awareness component. This effort will draw on a variety of agencies in the capital markets to define the substantive message, and on local mass media organizations and professionals to refine the strategy and select the most effective media vehicles. Agreements Between the Borrower and Implementation Agencies 6. The Borrower is the Republic of Croatia, represented by its Ministry of Finance. 7. The Loan finances, among other things, the development of securities depository, registry, clearing and settlement facilities (the "depository", for brevity). These facilities currently exist as a registered legal entity with both public and private equity capital: WS. However, they must be developed and made operational. 8. To avoid the delays and risks of building the administrative apparatus from scratch, as an interim measure, the Government has decided to utilize the administrative and technical resources of the Institute for Payment Transactions (ZZPP) to make the depository operational. However, to preserve and extend the capital markets' oversight of the critical depository function, WS will retain its legal and financial identity. During the initial development phase, a formal contract between WS and ZZPP will govern ZZPP's responsibilities, resource contributions and how those contributions will be reflected in WS's capitalization and governance. Details of these arrangements will be based on a strategic analysis of the securities depository, registry, clearing and settlement functions in the Croatian context. (See Annex D on page 45 for a description of this analysis.) 9. To ensure long term, private sector oversight of WS, the MOF will seek majority private sector shareholding of WS at the earliest possible date. The timing of the privatization will depend on a number of factors, including: (i) the scope of WS's responsibilities (as determined through the strategic analysis); (ii) the speed and cost of the development and implementation work; (iii) the strength of private sector entities in the capital markets; and (iv) the evolution of the demand for WS services. Given the transitional environment of the Croatian economy, these factors have a high degree of uncertainty. Nevertheless, an operational depository with an initial business record will emerge by the end of the project period and provide a concrete basis for the Government to formulate its privatization plans.

 CROATIA: Capital Markets Development Project -- 5 -- Project Implementation Plan 10. Notwithstanding the Government's objective to privatize VVS, it will have to assess what, if any, public service functions VVS will undertake and how these will be reflected in VVS funding and governance. Specifically, during the initial phases of corporate privatizations as well as the subsequent rationalization of enterprise ownership, VVS will perform a major public service by lowering the risk of misadministration of the depository functions, by, among other things, economizing on scarce supervisory resources. Given the public's limited understanding of capital markets and their not altogether benign experiences with the formal financial sector (e.g., the so-called "Frozen Deposits"), lowering these risks is critical for the viability of the capital markets and, consequently, for the privatization program and the overall economic transformation. Once this transition period has given way to more stable and conventional securities trading patterns, however, VVS will face a significantly different demand for its services. 11. Given the unavoidable uncertainty over the evolution of the demand for trading and shareholder services, as well as the costs of operating VVS in the post-transition period (i.e. after project completion), the Government will have to determine what, if any, continued public financial support it will provide to VVS and how this will be reflected in VVS's governance arrangements. The strategic analysis for the depository functions includes the formulation of a business and financing model to assist the authorities in these decisions. The project also provides support for a privatization plan for VVS (most likely to be undertaken during the last year of the project). 1 2. The privatization plan must address, among other things, the fact that the depository's functional requirements and most appropriate institutional arrangements will change over time. For example, although the preliminary design anticipates a centralized depository, with securities accounts tracked to the final customer level (i.e., a one tier, "single vault" architecture), this design reflects the current weakness of alternative institutions in Croatia and the fragility of the public's confidence in the formal financial system. In a few years time, an increase in the capacity of banks and brokers to offer high fidelity depository, registry, clearing and settlement services and the public's greater familiarity with capital markets will open the possibility to move to a more distributed, multi-tier, multi-vault depository architecture. At this stage, and as part of the privatization process, VVS could be required to achieve financial self-sufficiency (if it had not already). In turn, full cost recovery may lead to the then infrequently and closely traded securities devolving to banks and brokers for depository services. VVS may then refocus on the accounts of the direct market participants (brokers, dealers, banks and institutional investors) and on a smaller number of key publicly traded securities. The strategic decisions, such as whether or not to distribute the depository functions, will require careful monitoring of evolution of the market, by CROSEC, the MOF, the National Bank of Croatia and other key capital markets policy makers. Also, such changes are likely to require revisions to the legal and financial arrangements of VVS. The privatization plan will need to address these issues as well as the appropriate regulatory structures to ensure that the public interest is properly served.

 CROATIA: Capital Markets Development Project - 27 -- PIP Annex A: TOR #1 REPUBLIC OF CROATIA Capital Markets Development Project Terms of Reference #1 Technical Assistance for the Establishment and Development of the Croatian Securities and Exchange Commission (CROSEC) DRAFT: February 15, 1996 Background 1. During 1993-4 Croatia accomplished one of the most successful macroeconomic stabilizations on record. Strict fiscal and monetary policies brought inflation down from near hyper-inflationary levels in 1993 to low single digit annual rates through 1994 where it has remained. To solidify these gains, to address public sector financial imbalances and to set the stage for long term, private sector led growth, the govemment has been shifting socially operated enterprises into private hands, through buyouts, auctions, vouchers and other methods. Currently, most of the roughly three thousand enterprises have been corporatized and a large fraction of the equity is held directly by about three quarters of a million citizens (out of a population of four and a half million). Liberalization and stabilization have also prompted an inflow of funds from the roughly two million diaspora Croats as well as from the off-shore savings of residents. 2. Continued privatization is central to achieving a sustainable fiscal balance and economic growth. However, like all transforming formerly socialist economies, Croatia is struggling to devise a privatization strategy that balances equity, economic efficiency and expediency. The country's weak, incomplete and illiquid capital markets significantly complicate this problem and constrain the authorities' options. The absence of appropriate regulation and supervision in the securities markets are particular concerns, as are the inadequate common "back office" facilities to support debt and equities trading. Together with the public's poor understanding of capital markets, these weakness present serious risks to the ongoing economic transformation program. 3. Accordingly, the Republic of Croatia has requested and received a loan of approximately US$9.5 million equivalent from the World Bank (IBRD) to help finance the costs of the Capital Markets Development Project. The project will: a. Strengthen the legal and policy framework of the capital markets, including the establishment of the Croatian Securities and Exchange Commission (CROSEC).

During 1 993-4 Croatia accomplished one of the most successful macroeconomic stabilizations on record. Strict fiscal and monetary policies brought inflation down from near hyper-inflationary levels in 1993 to low single digit annual rates through 1994 where it has remained. To solidify these gains, to address public sector financial imbalances and to set the stage for long term, private sector led growth, the government has been shifting socially operated enterprises into private hands, through buyouts, auctions, vouchers and other methods. Currently, most of the roughly three thousand enterprises have been corporatized and a large fraction of the equity is held directly by about three quarters of a million citizens (out of a population of four and a half million). Liberalization and stabilization have also prompted an inflow of funds from the roughly two million diaspora Croats as well as from the off-shore savings of residents. 2. Continued privatization is central to achieving a sustainable fiscal balance and economic growth. However, like all transforming formerly socialist economies, Croatia is struggling to devise a privatization strategy that balances -equity, economic efficiency and expediency. The country's weak, incomplete and illiquid capital markets significantly complicate this problem and constrain the authorities' options. The absence of appropriate regulation and supervision in the securities markets are particular concerns, as are the inadequate common "back office" facilities to support debt and equities trading. Together with the public's poor understanding of capital markets, these weakness present serious risks to the ongoing economic transformation program.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Capital Markets Development Project are to strengthen key government areas, including: (a) the regulatory and policy framework of the capital markets; (b) the infrastructure to support securities transactions; and (c) the public's understanding of the capital markets and their roles as shareholders of privatized firms. The project consists of three components. The policy support component supports development of a legal and regulatory framework. The infrastructure development component provides technical assistance, equipment and facilities investments to establish and strengthen the securities depository, registry, clearing and settlement facilities. Finally, the public awareness component provides technical assistance to devise, develop and execute a mass media public awareness campaign. The campaign seeks to improve the general public's understanding of the capital markets and of their role and rights as participants.
